title: A ranked ladder that does not represent the player but the inconstancies of their teammates.
body:
The current system known as MMR and it face value counterpart LP is a false system of representation. 

The system right now does not express the individual player skill but the inconsistency of his/her teammates' skill. Furthermore, the algorithm for calculating MMR should be made public so people can know exactly what went into the making /result of a game, pre-game through post-game for all members of a played game. Thus allowing players more insight into improving the chances of repeating the desired outcome of their play and diminishing upon undesired results. Basically, I am asking for there to be more transparency on Riot's side about everything MMR related. Also, I'd like to know more about their philosophy as to what the ranked ladder is in theory intended to represent and how well they feel the current ladder does hold true to their philosophy of the ranked ladder. Ultimately I am of the opinion that the ranked ladder MMR system should be revisited and improved upon.

replies.body: What most people don't understand is that your understanding of the macro game, and ability to apply it and get your teammates to apply it is the biggest factor in winning.  Letting yourself believe it's the troll teammates that make you lose and not yourself is the biggest cop out that everyone uses.  Rarely do you actually have someone "running it down."  it's the mental party or the game that makes the good players good.

Yes, macro without a doubt wins the game. But you can only control your own macro, not your teams. You can ask but people flat out don't listen or fail miserably at applying the concept. Why should a players' MMR be decided by thair teammates' randomized reliability?

You play more selfish champs. Split pushers, solo carries, assassins, etc. Champs that can 1v1, 1v2. I mean when I play Varus or Ashe, I know I'm gonna be relying on a lot of teamwork to win that game. Could probably just play Nasus/Trynd/Fizz/whatever and treat all my teammates like banner minions. Oh hey, I need to get my 2 banner minions bot pushing, lets go gank bot lane get that banner Rot going.

I'd just play really selfish champs if I was you. You can't be maining top lane tanks or something and not expect your games to rely heavily on teamwork.
So basically, if you're a support main, whether you will win or not is literally a dice roll at lower elo.

>
> So basically, if you're a support main, whether you will win or not is literally a dice roll at lower elo.

No. Supports single handedly win botlane. Really, if you want to see why a botlane loses just look down there and see which support is being more active and that'll tell you which one is going to win. If botlane is the most important lane in the game, supports are the most important part of it for the first 5-10 minutes. 

There are selfish support champs, too. Brand/Zyra/Velkoz etc. Champs who do a ton of damage, and can carry games, and can destroy enemy botlanes 1v2 without any help from their ADC. 

Not to mention, most of them are playmakers, free to roam the map and make plays and push their teammates where they want. And, the primary source of vision in solo Q where no one hardly ever buys vision.

If anything, the most team reliant positions are probably tank tops and most ADCs, like Kog/Varus/Ashe/etc. Champs like Trist/Vayne/Kaisa can do their own things.

> [{quoted}](name=Notion Z,realm=NA,application-id=3ErqAdtq,discussion-id=9jqGaV2Z,comment-id=00020001,timestamp=2018-04-20T19:31:51.166+0000)
>
> Yes, macro without a doubt wins the game. But you can only control your own macro, not your teams. You can ask but people flat out don't listen or fail miserably at applying the concept. Why should a players' MMR be decided by thair teammates' randomized reliability?

You can only control your own macro, but you can still influence the entire game.  If you can get a random group of people to work with you, that's a leadership skill that can't be measured by stats.  It's not easy but pulling it off once every 20 games will up your win rate by 5%.

Learning to overcome less than ideal situations is a skill.

A game with "bad" teammates might have a 10% chance of winning but if your skill can turn it into a 15% chance, you will increase your MMR over time.

Rarely do you actually have someone "running it down."  it's the mental party or the game that makes the good players good.

Its because League is actually a fairly easy game to play. Your champ is not that hard to control. You have 4 abilities. Its not hard to get mechanically proficient at your champion. Its one of the charms of the game, and why so many people play it. You FEEL good at the game. So people FEEL they deserve higher elo because they play their champ so well. Well, there is more to the game, and more to winning, than mastering your 4 buttons. League is mostly about decision making, like you said. Its the equivalent of driving a stick shift. Just learning how to drive your stick shift does not make you an amazing driver. Just learning how to control your champ respectfully doesnt mean you are so good at the game you deserve higher elo.

I can honestly say in my own experience, what holds me back the most is poor mid-game management. I lane well, I have good mechanics for the most part(who doesn't), but I'm just lost a lot of times running around mid game doing nothing productive. Maybe copying something I saw on a stream or LCS. End up pushing a wave when I should be teamfighting. End up bot when I should be top. End up doing Krugs when I should be doing this. Having poor map awareness. The actual control of my character is almost never what causes me to lose games.

ALl the evidence shows that individual skill has highest factor. If it was based on RNG with teammates people wouldnt be same ranks as always with minor differences. You dont have people who were bronze and silver for few seasons suddenly in plat or diamond or plat, gold players suddenly in Bronze.

Do you feel that individual skill in represented enough? For instance what if winning or losing lp was mitigated by the individual's performance? This would help those of consistent play and dampen the harm done by the randomized inconsistencies of the players he/she cannot control. It would also lessen the gains for players that got carried.

Yes, i do. 

They cant make LP gain/loss based on performance. How would they determine performance? Based on grade? I can get S every game without contributing at all. Based on CS? KDA? All of that encourage solo play, splitpushing and fucks team oriented champions. There are also many strategies that dont get graded well but heavily contribute to win. Also if game didnt start well, why bother helping team and making any risks that could ruin my score?  No. LP gain/loss MUST only be ever determined based on win/loss because only then will people be motivated to actually win.

>I can get S every game without contributing at all. 

I don't think this is accurate. If you got an S rank, you're warding, have good CS, good KDA, and probably assisted in an objective or two.

Your score depends on averages for that champion, as an example check my last match as Vi. I did the least damage in the game (less then both supports), contributed very little to objective play and I even forgot to buy at the start and thus farmed half my jungle with no items, putting myself behind.l for the first 15 mins of the game. I still got an S though because Vi is weak right now and thus me literally being carried didn't matter.

Furthermore warding a lot, having a decent kd and CS is not indicative of contributing to victory.

Griefing.
I agree that the only way to gain LP/MMR is to win but I think that LP/MMR gain/loss should be mitigated by individual performance not solely on win rate.
Don't play a team game if you think that your progression should not be inhibited by the quality of your team mates.

In a game where 9 other players (either known or unknown) are added to your queue, the ability to win a game by oneself depends entirely upon the performance of you, your teammates, and your opponents with respect to in-game circumstances, positioning, types of champions, item builds, and decision making.  All of these factors are relevant for determining the outcome of the game, most of which is not under any specific player's control.

In a game where 1 player can decide each of the above categories for themselves, that results in:

4 lanes to play (jungle as a lane) x 5 roles to choose from x 11 summoner spells x 2 summoner spells to pick x 16 major rune keystones x 46 subset rune choices x 124 champions to choose from x 222 potential items to choose from all maps and game modes x 10 players to make individual decisions = 980,613,427,200 potential choices to make in a single game.

Now as a single player, that results in:
4 lanes to play (jungle as a lane) x 5 roles to choose from x 11 summoner spells x 2 summoner spells to pick x 16 major rune keystones x 46 subset rune choices x 124 champions to choose from x 222 potential items to choose from all maps and game modes x 1 player to make individual decisions = 98,061,342,720 potential choices to make in a single game.

Therefore, the chance any singular player has at carrying and winning a game based on their decision alone at best is:
98,061,342,720  / 980,613,427,200 = 10%

So, that means you have a 10% chance of establishing victorious conditions for your team, whereas the other 90% of your win condition depends on the performance, collaboration, and decision making of your teammates as well as your opponents.

Under these circumstances, I would say that any form of ranked ladder in any competitive, multi-player based game like League of Legends that relies on you playing with unknown teammates shows in large majority the performance and consistency of those teammates (or lack thereof).

P.S. - these math calculations don't account for the multitude of decisions one can make in-game.

Personally, I'd say inconsistency of teammates and opponents.

This season, most of my games have been a nearly 10k gold difference by 15 minutes! With one team having an insurmountable lead and skill difference right from the start.
